Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Duress due to forced conscription into NPFL
Crimes.Evidence_Requirement: Evidence of participation and opportunity to escape
Crimes.Institutional_Action: Refusal of admission based on membership and conduct
Crimes.Government_Body_or_Authority: Immigration Division of the Immigration and Refugee Board
Crimes.Nature_of_Participation: Active involvement in NPFL raids over four years
Crimes.Temporal_Context: Four-year period during Liberian civil conflict
Crimes.Complaint_Issues: Alleged ignoring of evidence and unreasonable application of duress
Crimes.Protection_Claim: Refugee protection based on fear of persecution
Crimes.State_Protection_Assessment: Opportunity to seek protection by escaping NPFL
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Involvement in violent raids and atrocities
Crimes.Credibility: Partially accepted but outweighed by evidence of complicity
Crimes.State_Protection_Adequacy: Deemed adequate through possibility of escape
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Perpetration of violence rather than victimization
Crimes.Legal_Basis: Membership and active participation in organization committing crimes against humanity

Crimes.National_Security_Element: Association with NPFL, designated as terrorist entity
Crimes.National_Security_Danger: Potential threat due to past involvement in terrorism
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: Ongoing risk based on extensive participation
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Duration and nature of involvement with NPFL
Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Participation in violent raids and atrocities
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Credibility of duress claim versus evidence of voluntary participation
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Duress claim undermined by evidence of opportunities to escape
Crimes.Credibility_Factors: Contradictions in narrative, lack of attempt to flee
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Claim of duress not fully accepted
Crimes.Evidence_Issues: Weight given to behavioral patterns over self-reporting
Crimes.Authority_Decision: Found Jalloh was a member of a terrorist organization
Crimes.Process: Administrative hearing followed by judicial review
Crimes.Procedural_Element: Burden of proof on applicant to rebut inadmissibility
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Claim of inadequate consideration of duress
Crimes.Review_Standard: Patent unreasonableness and correctness where applicable
Crimes.Reasoning_Deficiency: Alleged failure to consider medical evidence of PTSD

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether membership in NPFL constitutes inadmissibility under IRPA
Crimes.Application_Facts: Jalloh admitted involvement with NPFL but claimed duress
Crimes.Defendant_Behavior: Active participation in NPFL military operations
Crimes.Assessment_Factor: Opportunity to escape and level of complicity
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Allegation that Board failed to properly assess duress
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Duress defense rejected based on conduct and choices
Crimes.Application_Basis: Membership in organization engaged in subversion and terrorism
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient proof of inability to escape
Crimes.Harm_Assessment: Risk of reintegration into society due to past actions
Crimes.Cause_Description: Alleged forced conscription into NPFL during Liberian civil war
Crimes.Evidence_Handling: Board weighed all evidence including credibility and context
Crimes.Evidence_Issues: Weight assigned to duress claim vs. active participation
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Canadian immigration law applying extraterritorial conduct
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Comprehensive evaluation of testimony and behavior
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Active and sustained participation negates duress defense
Crimes.Evidentiary_Issues: Sufficiency and credibility of duress claims
